>The argument in favour of using new specific types seems to
> imply that m=
aking the intent visible on the network is both possible
> and desirable. I=
 don't think either of those assumptions holds true

And this is also a cri=
tical question of this discussion.

Media-types like images benefit from ne=
twork visibility - for instance when using the Opera Mini browser that depe=
nds on Operas servers to reduce the size of the images on the network.

But=
 it is hard to argue that network visibility is desirable with examples of =
more problem domain specific media types (like for instance application/vnd=
.imageprocessing+xml) since we cannot come up with good use cases for that.=
 But allow me to try anyway ...

Assume we have two companies working toget=
her on e-commerce, but due to historical reasons they use different domain =
specific media-types. If these types are visible on the network then we can=
 (in theory) have transparent/invisible intermediates that transform back-a=
nd-forth when communicating with the other business. Just as we can transfo=
rm images.

The same could of course be done on the clients instead of insi=
de the network - but Opera Mini do not do that for good reasons.

Using net=
work visible media-types opens up for use cases that we cannot imagine righ=
t now. Like the Opera Mini use case.

/J=F8rn
